newsitem.title: USA: H-P to unveil wireless mail for palmtops.
newsitem.headline: H-P to unveil wireless mail for palmtops.

text.p: Hewlett-Packard Co will on Wednesday unveil new packages enabling customers to use its handheld palmtop personal computers to send and receive wireless Internet electronic mail.

Representatives of the Palo Alto-based company said the company will launch HP Partner Kits providing all-in-one wireless Internet e-mail packages with easy set-up and modem rental in conjunction with its high tech partners.

Analysts said the initiative, dubbed "no wait, no wires," is part of a broader effort among companies supporting Microsoft Corp's Windows CE mobile computing environment as part of a new category of products.

"H-P -- and a lot of others -- are beginning to really push the whole concept of wireless connectivity for e-mail as stage for other kinds of palmtop devices," said Tim Bajarin, who heads the consulting firm Creative Strategies.
H-P's announcement will provide new services for its HP 200LX palmtop PC, but analysts expect it to broaden and expand its palmtop offerings in the near future as well.
H-P's partners include PC card providers U.S. Robotics Corp and Motorola Inc, and wireless network providers RAM Mobile Data, a partnership of RAM Broadcasting and BellSouth, and Ardis.

Wynd Communications Corp and RadioMail Corp will be service providers for the wireless e-mail services, with both offering a range of services which include e-mail, faxing, paging and Internet-based information services.
Industry analysts expect electronic mail to continue to be one of the most important applications for mobile computing.

Hewlett-Packard is expected to make the Internet mail package available through retailers Office Max, Office Depot, Computer City, CompUSA and PC Warehouse, while a reseller version will be offered by Merisel, Ingram and Gates Arrow.
